<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html b:version='2' class='v2' expr:dir='data:blog.languageDirection' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml' xmlns:b='http://www.google.com/2005/gml/b' xmlns:data='http://www.google.com/2005/gml/data' xmlns:expr='http://www.google.com/2005/gml/expr'>
  <head>
    <meta content='IE=EmulateIE7' http-equiv='X-UA-Compatible'/>
    <b:if cond='data:blog.isMobile'>
      <meta content='width=device-width,initial-scale=1.0,minimum-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0' name='viewport'/>
    <b:else/>
      <meta content='width=1100' name='viewport'/>
    </b:if>

    <title><data:blog.pageTitle/></title>

    <b:skin><![CDATA[/*
-----------------------------------------------
Blogger Template Style
Name:     Simple
Designer: Josh Peterson
URL:      www.noaesthetic.com
----------------------------------------------- */

/* Variable definitions
   ====================
   <Variable name="keycolor" description="Main Color" type="color" default="#66bbdd" value="#dd7700"/>

   <Group description="Page Text" selector="body">
     <Variable name="body.font" description="Font" type="font"
         default="normal normal 12px Arial, Tahoma, Helvetica, FreeSans, sans-serif" value="normal normal 12px Arial, Tahoma, Helvetica, FreeSans, sans-serif"/>
     <Variable name="body.text.color" description="Text Color" type="color" default="#222222" value="#cccccc"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Backgrounds" selector=".body-fauxcolumns-outer">
     <Variable name="body.background.color" description="Outer Background" type="color" default="#66bbdd" value="#292929"/>
     <Variable name="content.background.color" description="Main Background" type="color" default="#ffffff" value="#333333"/>
     <Variable name="header.background.color" description="Header Background" type="color" default="transparent" value="transparent"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Links" selector=".main-outer">
     <Variable name="link.color" description="Link Color" type="color" default="#2288bb" value="#dd7700"/>
     <Variable name="link.visited.color" description="Visited Color" type="color" default="#888888" value="#cc6600"/>
     <Variable name="link.hover.color" description="Hover Color" type="color" default="#33aaff" value="#cc6600"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Blog Title" selector=".header h1">
     <Variable name="header.font" description="Font" type="font"
         default="normal normal 60px Arial, Tahoma, Helvetica, FreeSans, sans-serif" value="normal normal 60px Arial, Tahoma, Helvetica, FreeSans, sans-serif"/>
     <Variable name="header.text.color" description="Title Color" type="color" default="#3399bb"  value="#ffffff"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Blog Description" selector=".header .description">
     <Variable name="description.text.color" description="Description Color" type="color"
         default="#777777"  value="#aaaaaa"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Tabs Text" selector=".tabs-inner .widget li a">
     <Variable name="tabs.font" description="Font" type="font"
         default="normal normal 14px Arial, Tahoma, Helvetica, FreeSans, sans-serif" value="normal normal 14px Arial, Tahoma, Helvetica, FreeSans, sans-serif"/>
     <Variable name="tabs.text.color" description="Text Color" type="color" default="#999999" value="#999999"/>
     <Variable name="tabs.selected.text.color" description="Selected Color" type="color" default="#000000" value="#ffffff"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Tabs Background" selector=".tabs-outer .PageList">
     <Variable name="tabs.background.color" description="Background Color" type="color" default="#f5f5f5" value="#222222"/>
     <Variable name="tabs.selected.background.color" description="Selected Color" type="color" default="#eeeeee" value="#000000"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Post Title" selector="h3.post-title, .comments h4">
     <Variable name="post.title.font" description="Font" type="font"
         default="normal normal 22px Arial, Tahoma, Helvetica, FreeSans, sans-serif" value="normal normal 22px Arial, Tahoma, Helvetica, FreeSans, sans-serif"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Date Header" selector=".date-header">
     <Variable name="date.header.color" description="Text Color" type="color"
         default="$(body.text.color)" value="$(body.text.color)"/>
     <Variable name="date.header.background.color" description="Background Color" type="color"
         default="transparent" value="transparent"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Post Footer" selector=".post-footer">
     <Variable name="post.footer.text.color" description="Text Color" type="color" default="#666666" value="#888888"/>
     <Variable name="post.footer.background.color" description="Background Color" type="color"
         default="#f9f9f9" value="#303030"/>
     <Variable name="post.footer.border.color" description="Shadow Color" type="color" default="#eeeeee" value="#444444"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Gadgets" selector="h2">
     <Variable name="widget.title.font" description="Title Font" type="font"
        default="normal bold 11px Arial, Tahoma, Helvetica, FreeSans, sans-serif" value="normal bold 11px Arial, Tahoma, Helvetica, FreeSans, sans-serif"/>
     <Variable name="widget.title.text.color" description="Title Color" type="color" default="#000000" value="#ffffff"/>
     <Variable name="widget.alternate.text.color" description="Alternate Color" type="color" default="#999999" value="#999999"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Images" selector=".main-inner">
     <Variable name="image.background.color" description="Background Color" type="color" default="#ffffff" value="#111111"/>
     <Variable name="image.border.color" description="Border Color" type="color" default="#eeeeee" value="#111111"/>
     <Variable name="image.text.color" description="Caption Text Color" type="color" default="$(body.text.color)" value="$(body.text.color)"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Accents" selector=".content-inner">
     <Variable name="body.rule.color" description="Separator Line Color" type="color" default="#eeeeee" value="#404040"/>
     <Variable name="tabs.border.color" description="Tabs Border Color" type="color" default="$(body.rule.color)" value="$(body.rule.color)"/>
   </Group>

   <Variable name="body.background" description="Body Background" type="background"
       color="$(body.background.color)" default="$(color) none repeat scroll top left" value="$(color) none repeat scroll top left"/>
   <Variable name="body.background.override" description="Body Background Override" type="string" default="" value=""/>

   <Variable name="body.background.gradient.cap" description="Body Gradient Cap" type="url"
       default="url(//www.blogblog.com/1kt/simple/gradients_light.png)" value="none"/>
   <Variable name="body.background.gradient.tile" description="Body Gradient Tile" type="url"
       default="url(//www.blogblog.com/1kt/simple/body_gradient_tile_light.png)" value="none"/>

   <Variable name="content.background.color.selector" description="Content Background Color Selector" type="string" default=".content-inner" value=".content-inner"/>
   <Variable name="content.padding" description="Content Padding" type="length" default="10px" value="10px"/>
   <Variable name="content.padding.horizontal" description="Content Horizontal Padding" type="length" default="$(content.padding)" value="$(content.padding)"/>
   <Variable name="content.shadow.spread" description="Content Shadow Spread" type="length" default="40px" value="40px"/>
   <Variable name="content.shadow.spread.webkit" description="Content Shadow Spread (WebKit)" type="length" default="5px" value="5px"/>
   <Variable name="content.shadow.spread.ie" description="Content Shadow Spread (IE)" type="length" default="10px" value="10px"/>

   <Variable name="main.border.width" description="Main Border Width" type="length" default="0" value="0"/>

   <Variable name="header.background.gradient" description="Header Gradient" type="url" default="none" value="none"/>
   <Variable name="header.shadow.offset.left" description="Header Shadow Offset Left" type="length" default="-1px" value="-1px"/>
   <Variable name="header.shadow.offset.top" description="Header Shadow Offset Top" type="length" default="-1px" value="-1px"/>
   <Variable name="header.shadow.spread" description="Header Shadow Spread" type="length" default="1px" value="1px"/>
   <Variable name="header.padding" description="Header Padding" type="length" default="30px" value="30px"/>

   <Variable name="header.border.size" description="Header Border Size" type="length" default="1px" value="1px"/>
   <Variable name="header.bottom.border.size" description="Header Bottom Border Size" type="length" default="$(header.border.size)" value="$(header.border.size)"/>
   <Variable name="header.border.horizontalsize" description="Header Horizontal Border Size" type="length" default="0" value="0"/>

   <Variable name="description.text.size" description="Description Text Size" type="string" default="140%" value="140%"/>

   <Variable name="tabs.margin.top" description="Tabs Margin Top" type="length" default="0"  value="0"/>
   <Variable name="tabs.margin.side" description="Tabs Side Margin" type="length" default="30px"  value="30px"/>
   <Variable name="tabs.background.gradient" description="Tabs Background Gradient" type="url"
       default="url(//www.blogblog.com/1kt/simple/gradients_light.png)" value="none"/>
   <Variable name="tabs.border.width" description="Tabs Border Width" type="length" default="1px" value="1px"/>
   <Variable name="tabs.bevel.border.width" description="Tabs Bevel Border Width" type="length" default="1px" value="0"/>

   <Variable name="date.header.padding" description="Date Header Padding" type="string" default="inherit" value="inherit"/>
   <Variable name="date.header.letterspacing" description="Date Header Letter Spacing" type="string" default="inherit" value="inherit"/>
   <Variable name="date.header.margin" description="Date Header Margin" type="string" default="inherit" value="inherit"/>

   <Variable name="post.margin.bottom" description="Post Bottom Margin" type="length" default="25px" value="25px"/>

   <Variable name="image.border.small.size" description="Image Border Small Size" type="length" default="2px" value="0"/>
   <Variable name="image.border.large.size" description="Image Border Large Size" type="length" default="5px" value="1px"/>

   <Variable name="page.width.selector" description="Page Width Selector" type="string" default=".region-inner" value=".region-inner"/>
   <Variable name="page.width" description="Page Width" type="string" default="auto" value="auto"/>

   <Variable name="main.section.margin" description="Main Section Margin" type="length" default="15px" value="15px"/>
   <Variable name="main.padding" description="Main Padding" type="length" default="15px" value="15px"/>
   <Variable name="main.padding.top" description="Main Padding Top" type="length" default="30px" value="30px"/>
   <Variable name="main.padding.bottom" description="Main Padding Bottom" type="length" default="30px" value="30px"/>

   <Variable name="paging.background"
       color="$(content.background.color)"
       description="Background of blog paging area" type="background"
       default="transparent none no-repeat scroll top center" value="transparent none no-repeat scroll top center"/>

   <Variable name="footer.bevel" description="Bevel border length of footer" type="length" default="0" value="0"/>

   <Variable name="mobile.background.overlay" description="Mobile Background Overlay" type="string"
       default="transparent none repeat scroll top left" value="transparent none repeat scroll top left"/>
   <Variable name="mobile.background.size" description="Mobile Background Size" type="string" default="auto" value="auto"/>
   <Variable name="mobile.button.color" description="Mobile Button Color" type="color" default="#ffffff"  value="#ffffff"/>

   <Variable name="startSide" description="Side where text starts in blog language" type="automatic" default="left" value="left"/>
   <Variable name="endSide" description="Side where text ends in blog language" type="automatic" default="right" value="right"/>
*/

/* Content
----------------------------------------------- */
body {
  font: $(body.font);
  color: $(body.text.color);
  background: $(body.background);
  padding: 0 $(content.shadow.spread) $(content.shadow.spread) $(content.shadow.spread);
  $(body.background.override)
}

html body $(page.width.selector) {
  min-width: 0;
  max-width: 100%;
  width: $(page.width);
}

a:link {
  text-decoration:none;
  color: $(link.color);
}

a:visited {
  text-decoration:none;
  color: $(link.visited.color);
}

a:hover {
  text-decoration:underline;
  color: $(link.hover.color);
}

.body-fauxcolumn-outer .fauxcolumn-inner {
  background: transparent $(body.background.gradient.tile) repeat scroll top left;
  _background-image: none;
}

.body-fauxcolumn-outer .cap-top {
  position: absolute;
  z-index: 1;
  height: 400px;
  width: 100%;
  background: $(body.background);
  $(body.background.override)
}

.body-fauxcolumn-outer .cap-top .cap-left {
  width: 100%;
  background: transparent $(body.background.gradient.cap) repeat-x scroll top left;
  _background-image: none;
}

.content-outer {
  -moz-box-shadow: 0 0 $(content.shadow.spread) rgba(0, 0, 0, .15);
  -webkit-box-shadow: 0 0 $(content.shadow.spread.webkit) rgba(0, 0, 0, .15);
  -goog-ms-box-shadow: 0 0 $(content.shadow.spread.ie) #333333;
  box-shadow: 0 0 $(content.shadow.spread) rgba(0, 0, 0, .15);

  margin-bottom: 1px;
}

.content-inner {
  padding: $(content.padding) $(content.padding.horizontal);
}

$(content.background.color.selector) {
  background-color: $(content.background.color);
}

/* Header
----------------------------------------------- */
.header-outer {
  background: $(header.background.color) $(header.background.gradient) repeat-x scroll 0 -400px;
  _background-image: none;
}

.Header h1 {
  font: $(header.font);
  color: $(header.text.color);
  text-shadow: $(header.shadow.offset.left) $(header.shadow.offset.top) $(header.shadow.spread) rgba(0, 0, 0, .2);
}

.Header h1 a {
  color: $(header.text.color);
}

.Header .description {
  font-size: $(description.text.size);
  color: $(description.text.color);
}

.header-inner .Header .titlewrapper {
  padding: 22px $(header.padding);
}

.header-inner .Header .descriptionwrapper {
  padding: 0 $(header.padding);
}

/* Tabs
----------------------------------------------- */
.tabs-inner .section:first-child {
  border-top: $(header.bottom.border.size) solid $(tabs.border.color);
}

.tabs-inner .section:first-child ul {
  margin-top: -$(header.border.size);
  border-top: $(header.border.size) solid $(tabs.border.color);
  border-left: $(header.border.horizontalsize) solid $(tabs.border.color);
  border-right: $(header.border.horizontalsize) solid $(tabs.border.color);
}

.tabs-inner .widget ul {
  background: $(tabs.background.color) $(tabs.background.gradient) repeat-x scroll 0 -800px;
  _background-image: none;
  border-bottom: $(tabs.border.width) solid $(tabs.border.color);

  margin-top: $(tabs.margin.top);
  margin-left: -$(tabs.margin.side);
  margin-right: -$(tabs.margin.side);
}

.tabs-inner .widget li a {
  display: inline-block;

  padding: .6em 1em;

  font: $(tabs.font);
  color: $(tabs.text.color);

  border-$startSide: $(tabs.border.width) solid $(content.background.color);
  border-$endSide: $(tabs.bevel.border.width) solid $(tabs.border.color);
}

.tabs-inner .widget li:first-child a {
  border-$startSide: none;
}

.tabs-inner .widget li.selected a, .tabs-inner .widget li a:hover {
  color: $(tabs.selected.text.color);
  background-color: $(tabs.selected.background.color);
  text-decoration: none;
}

/* Columns
----------------------------------------------- */
.main-outer {
  border-top: $(main.border.width) solid $(body.rule.color);
}

.fauxcolumn-left-outer .fauxcolumn-inner {
  border-right: 1px solid $(body.rule.color);
}

.fauxcolumn-right-outer .fauxcolumn-inner {
  border-left: 1px solid $(body.rule.color);
}

/* Headings
----------------------------------------------- */
h2 {
  margin: 0 0 1em 0;

  font: $(widget.title.font);
  color: $(widget.title.text.color);
}

/* Widgets
----------------------------------------------- */
.widget .zippy {
  color: $(widget.alternate.text.color);
  text-shadow: 2px 2px 1px rgba(0, 0, 0, .1);
}

.widget .popular-posts ul {
  list-style: none;
}

/* Posts
----------------------------------------------- */
.date-header span {
  background-color: $(date.header.background.color);
  color: $(date.header.color);
  padding: $(date.header.padding);
  letter-spacing: $(date.header.letterspacing);
  margin: $(date.header.margin);
}

.main-inner {
  padding-top: $(main.padding.top);
  padding-bottom: $(main.padding.bottom);
}

.main-inner .column-center-inner {
  padding: 0 $(main.padding);
}

.main-inner .column-center-inner .section {
  margin: 0 $(main.section.margin);
}

.post {
  margin: 0 0 $(post.margin.bottom) 0;
}

h3.post-title, .comments h4 {
  font: $(post.title.font);
  margin: .75em 0 0;
}

.post-body {
  font-size: 110%;
  line-height: 1.4;
  position: relative;
}

.post-body img, .post-body .tr-caption-container, .Profile img, .Image img,
.BlogList .item-thumbnail img {
  padding: $(image.border.small.size);

  background: $(image.background.color);
  border: 1px solid $(image.border.color);

  -moz-box-shadow: 1px 1px 5px rgba(0, 0, 0, .1);
  -webkit-box-shadow: 1px 1px 5px rgba(0, 0, 0, .1);
  box-shadow: 1px 1px 5px rgba(0, 0, 0, .1);
}

.post-body img, .post-body .tr-caption-container {
  padding: $(image.border.large.size);
}

.post-body .tr-caption-container {
  color: $(image.text.color);
}

.post-body .tr-caption-container img {
  padding: 0;

  background: transparent;
  border: none;

  -moz-box-shadow: 0 0 0 rgba(0, 0, 0, .1);
  -webkit-box-shadow: 0 0 0 rgba(0, 0, 0, .1);
  box-shadow: 0 0 0 rgba(0, 0, 0, .1);
}

.post-header {
  margin: 0 0 1.5em;

  line-height: 1.6;
  font-size: 90%;
}

.post-footer {
  margin: 20px -2px 0;
  padding: 5px 10px;

  color: $(post.footer.text.color);
  background-color: $(post.footer.background.color);
  border-bottom: 1px solid $(post.footer.border.color);

  line-height: 1.6;
  font-size: 90%;
}

#comments .comment-author {
  padding-top: 1.5em;

  border-top: 1px solid $(body.rule.color);
  background-position: 0 1.5em;
}

#comments .comment-author:first-child {
  padding-top: 0;
  border-top: none;
}

.avatar-image-container {
  margin: .2em 0 0;
}

#comments .avatar-image-container img {
  border: 1px solid $(image.border.color);
}

/* Comments
----------------------------------------------- */
.comments .comments-content .icon.blog-author {
  background-repeat: no-repeat;
  background-image: url(data:image/png;base64,);
}

.comments .comments-content .loadmore a {
  border-top: 1px solid $(widget.alternate.text.color);
  border-bottom: 1px solid $(widget.alternate.text.color);
}

.comments .comment-thread.inline-thread {
  background-color: $(post.footer.background.color);
}

.comments .continue {
  border-top: 2px solid $(widget.alternate.text.color);
}

/* Accents
---------------------------------------------- */
.section-columns td.columns-cell {
  border-$startSide: 1px solid $(body.rule.color);
}

.blog-pager {
  background: $(paging.background);
}

.blog-pager-older-link, .home-link,
.blog-pager-newer-link {
  background-color: $(content.background.color);
  padding: 5px;
}

.footer-outer {
  border-top: $(footer.bevel) dashed #bbbbbb;
}

/* Mobile
----------------------------------------------- */
body.mobile  {
  background-size: $(mobile.background.size);
}

.mobile .body-fauxcolumn-outer {
  background: $(mobile.background.overlay);
}

.mobile .body-fauxcolumn-outer .cap-top {
  background-size: 100% auto;
}

.mobile .content-outer {
  -webkit-box-shadow: 0 0 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, .15);
  box-shadow: 0 0 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, .15);
}

body.mobile .AdSense {
  margin: 0 -$(content.shadow.spread);
}

.mobile .tabs-inner .widget ul {
  margin-left: 0;
  margin-right: 0;
}

.mobile .post {
  margin: 0;
}

.mobile .main-inner .column-center-inner .section {
  margin: 0;
}

.mobile .date-header span {
  padding: 0.1em 10px;
  margin: 0 -10px;
}

.mobile h3.post-title {
  margin: 0;
}

.mobile .blog-pager {
  background: transparent none no-repeat scroll top center;
}

.mobile .footer-outer {
  border-top: none;
}

.mobile .main-inner, .mobile .footer-inner {
  background-color: $(content.background.color);
}

.mobile-index-contents {
  color: $(body.text.color);
}

.mobile-link-button {
  background-color: $(link.color);
}

.mobile-link-button a:link, .mobile-link-button a:visited {
  color: $(mobile.button.color);
}

.mobile .tabs-inner .section:first-child {
  border-top: none;
}

.mobile .tabs-inner .PageList .widget-content {
  background-color: $(tabs.selected.background.color);
  color: $(tabs.selected.text.color);
  border-top: $(tabs.border.width) solid $(tabs.border.color);
  border-bottom: $(tabs.border.width) solid $(tabs.border.color);
}

.mobile .tabs-inner .PageList .widget-content .pagelist-arrow {
  border-$startSide: 1px solid $(tabs.border.color);
}
]]></b:skin>

    <b:template-skin>
      <b:variable default='960px' name='content.width' type='length' value='1000px'/>
      <b:variable default='0' name='main.column.left.width' type='length' value='0px'/>
      <b:variable default='310px' name='main.column.right.width' type='length' value='260px'/>

      <![CDATA[
      body {
        min-width: $(content.width);
      }

      .content-outer, .content-fauxcolumn-outer, .region-inner {
        min-width: $(content.width);
        max-width: $(content.width);
        _width: $(content.width);
      }

      .main-inner .columns {
        padding-left: $(main.column.left.width);
        padding-right: $(main.column.right.width);
      }

      .main-inner .fauxcolumn-center-outer {
        left: $(main.column.left.width);
        right: $(main.column.right.width);
        /* IE6 does not respect left and right together */
        _width: expression(this.parentNode.offsetWidth -
            parseInt("$(main.column.left.width)") -
            parseInt("$(main.column.right.width)") + 'px');
      }

      .main-inner .fauxcolumn-left-outer {
        width: $(main.column.left.width);
      }

      .main-inner .fauxcolumn-right-outer {
        width: $(main.column.right.width);
      }

      .main-inner .column-left-outer {
        width: $(main.column.left.width);
        right: 100%;
        margin-left: -$(main.column.left.width);
      }

      .main-inner .column-right-outer {
        width: $(main.column.right.width);
        margin-right: -$(main.column.right.width);
      }

      #layout {
        min-width: 0;
      }

      #layout .content-outer {
        min-width: 0;
        width: 800px;
      }

      #layout .region-inner {
        min-width: 0;
        width: auto;
      }
      ]]>
    </b:template-skin>

XBMC Downloader, Part 1
entry.content:
The purpose of this guide is to modify a Linux-based XBMC distribution into an automated downloading station. I will do my best to explain every command and concept at the most basic level possible.

So you just finished installing XBMC. It works a treat and you have configured it to playback your carefully pruned media library of Movies and TV Shows.

I will assume that you are using one of the following platforms.


  • XBMCbuntu
  • Raspbmc
Here's a quick primer on all the names:

Linux (or GNU/Linux... don't get me started) is an open source operating system closely related to but not Unix.

  • Debian is a powerful, balanced distribution of Linux.


    • Ubuntu is a popular, easy to use spin-off Linux distribution that is built upon Debian.
      • XBMCbuntu is mostly Ubuntu with XBMC pre-installed and set to run on start up.
    • Raspbian is a version of Debian compiled for the unique processor ARM contained within the Raspberry Pi.
      • Raspbmc is mostly Raspbian with XBMC pre-installed and set to run on start up.
As you can see, both XBMC and Raspbmc operate on a Debian core. This means that commands and programs are mostly identical for our purposes.  Most people these days can run XBMC on their Raspberry Pi. I choose to run XBMC on an Asrock Ion 330 purely because I have one and it leaves my Pi for tinkering.  Technicalities aside, let's get down to business. What we want to do is upgrade our device so that it can download TV shows without a touch. Sounds impossible? Well, it isn't but explaining it all may prove painful to me. Luckily for you, you can make the most of my successes without wasting near as much time.  The first thing you want to do is get your XBMC checked out. Make sure it is happily playing back your local (or networked) movies and can play back a few YouTube clips.  On your XBMC interface, navigate to System --> System Info. On the Summary tab you should see the IP address of the machine.  All done here for now. Go find another computer and download PuTTY. Open it up and type in the IP address you saw on your XBMC. In my example it was 192.168.1.120.  Here's the part where, depending on your platform, what information you enter will differ. 

  • Raspbmc


    • Username: 




If you have Raspbmc, for your username type `pi` and for your password type `raspberry`

If you have XBMCbuntu, for your username type `xbmc` and leave your password blank, unless you [entered a password](http://wiki.xbmc.org/index.php?title=XBMCbuntu/FAQ#How_can_I_transfer_files_to.2Ffrom_XBMCbuntu.3F) when you first installed XBMCbuntu.

entry.title: Galaxy Nexus to Real Stock Android Guide
entry.content:
So I found out that my Galaxy Nexus gets its updates from Samsung (not Google) which get vetted by Optus before trickling down to my phone. See Elly's article on Gizmodo Australia for an excellent explanation.

So the low down is that if you buy your Galaxy Nexus from the Play Store, it will come with the vanilla Google build of Android, which at the time of writing is called Yakju.

On the other hand if you buy your Galaxy Nexus from a provider you will get another build of the OS, in my case Yakjuxw. This is a build that has gone through Samsung and Optus (of which Virgin is a subsidiary) before being installed on the device.

The obvious consequence is that when the Jelly Bean update comes out, my jelly beans will follow the same path as that of the build that came with my device. This means that instead of getting my Over The Air (OTA) updates straight from Google, I get them through Google, Samsung and then Optus.

This takes time, and at the time of writing, 4.0.4 is out but Optus are still on 4.0.2. Needless to say that my crappy carrier is unlikely to get off their collective asses just because a first-decimal update has come out.

So as it turns out, your "stock Android" as advertised by carriers and even the Samsung website, is not in fact properly stock Google. I thought that this was the whole point of the Nexus series, but it seems Google doesn't have the sense that Apple does, to whip carriers into shape and not let them bloat the process.

To fix this, I used Dax's guide from TheUnlockr for the most part, for which I thank him. He has on the most part made this guide from XDA-Developers more palatable, albeit with some things missing and some broken links.

We are going to be using the command line to interact with the phone while it is in a special Bootloader mode. To finish this project, we need three files:

1)----- Executable (binary) files containing the fastboot command. Dax's guide doesn't include a link to this. The following link is to the drivers for some other devices but the fastboot command is included and relevant to us. Download the file linked from this post on XDA-Developers.

2)----- The universal drivers to interact with your phone over USB. Again a kind person from XDA-Developers has created this and we will download this attachment from this post.

3)----- The Android operating system. Grab the file straight from Google to make sure you have the canonical version.

Firstly we're going to extract and mix up the files we've downloaded. Then we're going to install the files on your phone. Beware this will wipe your phone of all its data.

In your hard drive's root directory (for simplicity) create a folder called Android.

Open your Fastboot+ADB.zip and extract everything from the Win32 directory to your Android folder. We need adb.exe and fastboot.exe.

Open your Android operating system files and extract everything from the second nested archive (the Tar file, not the TGZ) into your Android folder.

Open your Android folder and you'll see a Zip file, extract the contents of this zip file into the Android folder.

Here are what you should have in your Android folder. I've excluded the irrelevant files so just make sure you have the following:
  • adb.exe
  • AdbWinApi.dll
  • AdbWinUsbApi.dll
  • boot.img
  • bootloader-magurao-primela03.img (or similar)
  • fastboot.exe
  • flash-all.sh
  • flash-base.sh
  • radio-maguro-i9250xxla02.img (or similar)
  • recover.img
  • system.img
  • userdata.img
Your Android folder is ready to go. We'll revisit this once we've got the device ready.

Turn off your phone. Hold down Volume Down and Volume Up and press the power button. You'll see your Android with his belly open telling you you're in the bootloader.

Plug your phone in via USB.

If your phone doesn't register, go to your device manager and right click on the unknown device, click Update Drivers and browser to your extracted Naked Drivers, the second file you downloaded. This should find the drivers for you and install them.

Now your phone is in the bootloader, your computer can see it and the Android folder is ready.

Open the command prompt as administrator (important) and navigate to your Android folder, made easy by its location at the root of the local hard drive.

Run the following commands:

fastboot devices

Hopefully some numbers should come up, meaning the command can see your phone. If not check your drivers and phone.

fastboot oem unlock

This unlocks the bootloader allowing custom firmware to be installed (what we're attempting) and will wipe your phone. You will have to allow this from your phone's screen.

fastboot reboot-bootloader

This will reboot back into the bootloader. So we can begin the installation. This is mostly straight from Dax with some help from the people who commented on his post.

fastboot flash system system.img
fastboot flash userdata userdata.img
fastboot flash boot boot.img
fastboot recovery recovery.img
fastboot erase cache
fastboot reboot

Each of these commands flashes a separate part of the phone (system, useradata, boot, recovery) with the new image downloaded straight from Google. The last two commands erase any previous settings and reboot the phone into the operating system.

That's it, you're starting from scratch but will have the latest pure Android stock operating system, straight from Google. You should also in future receive OTA updates from Google without any slowdowns from Samsung of your crappy carrier.

entry.title: Wget All Files of a Type (Regex)
entry.content:
To download all files of a certain extension using Wget in linux, I'll use the following command, which I made up while trying to leech the soundtrack for Descent 3.

wget -r -l1 --no-parent -erobots=off -A.zip http://archives.descent.cx/d3/d3music.html

wget is the program

-r


Runs wget recursively

-l1


Runs wget recursively but only to one level of depth

-no parent


Assures that wget won't exit the file hierarchy we gave it (the html file given).

-erobots=off


A naughty one, tells wget to ignore the robots.txt file, in this case blocking the automatic download. I'm not doing any too-intense downloads so I gave myself permission to do this, although it's technically faux pas.

-A.zip


Downloads all files ending in ".zip"

http://archives.descent.cx/d3/d3music.html


The starting point for the download query.

This successfully does a sequential download of the zip files that contain the songs I was looking for. Too bad I couln't find some of the levels, apparently the gentleman who uploaded them couldn't find the masters for those tracks. That's really too bad, I think we just lost a bit of game soundtrack history there. As small a piece as that is.

I found the link to the page from a Google search result, after an unsuccessful torrent search. Don't know how much longer that page will remain active though. :(

entry.title: DBAN on an HP Compaq DC7800
entry.content:
I recently challenged myself to wipe some HP Compaq DC7800 Small Form Factor PC (P/N GC760AV) that were being sold by my employer. IT support apparently take about a week to wipe a computer, so I thought I could to better.

First stop, Darik's Boot and Nuke, or DBAN in short. Darik provides a concise explanation of what his CD does:

"Darik's Boot and Nuke ("DBAN") is a self-contained boot disk that securely wipes the hard disks of most computers." (dban.org)

One of the first warnings, apart from the obvious permanence of the action you're about to take, is that Darik seems to not have maintained the software for a while. The latest versions (2.2.6 etc.) don't appear to work on most computers.

On the download page, avoid the main link and follow the link to Old Releases. There seems to be some issues with the latest release, which I found out about on the forums. I followed  krby1951's recommendation of using the old version 1.0.7.

This older version seems to be the standard (working) version that people recommend. The new versions doubtfully do much more and since they're buggy it wasn't worth my while fixing them.

Download "dban-1.0.7_i386.iso" and use something like ImgBurn to burn it to disk. If you didn't want to burn to disk and prefer a USB, use something like UNetbootin to "burn" it to USB. If you do, make sure your USB is FAT or FAT32. UNetbootin doesn't complain if your drive is NTFS (like mine) but you won't see much joy.

On HP Compaq DC7800 I booted into the DBAN CD by pressing F9 for the boot menu at the POST screen. The problem is that when I entered "autonuke" mode, I kept getting the following error:

DBAN Finished with non-fatal errors
This is usually caused by disks with bad sectors
Send the log file with all support requests

The strange thing was that one of my eight computers quite happily started wiping itself. The answer lies in the BIOS, then Storage, then Storage Options, where the "good" computer had "SATA Emulation" set to "IDE" and the "bad" computers had "SATA Emulation" set to "RAID".

Changing "SATA Emulation" to "IDE" requires confirmation after POST by pressing F1, after which you can again hit F9 to enter the boot menu after POST. Then once DBAN is up and running, hit "autonuke" and watch the highly specific carnage take place.

My eight computers are still going and look like they're going to take about 30 hours. They have 160GB hard drives. Get yourself some Peppermint Tisane (herbal tea) and relax, knowing that your data is being wiped to (outdated) U.S. Department of Defence standards.

link.title: DBAN on an HP Compaq DC7800

entry.title: Upgrading Ubuntu
entry.content:
Recently I noticed that my Ubuntu was out of date (11.04 instead of 11.10) so I embarked on a quest to update it.

I have used these two articles (first and second) and interpolated between them for the correct procedure.

First, do an update of your package lists:

sudo apt-get update

Then upgrade any packages that need upgrading:

sudo apt-get dist-upgrade

Now install the upgrade manager that will automate the process:

sudo apt-get install upgrade-manager-core

The second of the two articles mentioned fixing the following file to set a particular setting to the value 'normal'. I found that this was already the case, but then I might have fixed it previously.

Just in case, open the following file:

sudo vim /etc/update-manager/release upgrades

In this file, check and change if necessary the following setting:

Prompt=normal

I wondered what this did, so I did a bit of research and found the following page that described the change. What we did is that we changed the 'Prompt' setting from 'lts' which stands for Long Term Support to 'normal', which updates us to the latest normal release, not the latest LTS release. This is what we want for the latest possible version.

Before going ahead with the upgrade, do a backup of any important information you have on your server.

For me this included being a bit paranoid and backing up all small files in my /etc/ and /home/ directories using the following commands:

sudo rsync -av --max-size=25k --include=".**" --exclude="*" /home/eagle/ /md0/private/settings/eagle/

sudo rsync -av --max-size=25k /etc/ /md0/private/settings/etc/
sudo rsync -av --max-size=25k /var/spool/cron/ /md0/private/settings/cron/


With all my settings backed up and safe I thought I'd do one last thing and back up the following file in case I had trouble with my RAID array.

sudo cp /etc/mdadm/mdadm.conf /home/eagle/Dropbox/

Now hit the upgrade button:

sudo do-release-upgrade

You'll have to wait a while and keep an eye out for any prompts, so brew a cup of Rooibos tea, sit back and watch the magic happen.

entry.title: Pruning Your Media Library
entry.content:
Recently I used Media Master to add a whole bunch of metadata to my media library. As it turns out, I wanted to undo all of those changes. I wanted to delete the XML files that the program had put into each movie's folder, as well as the jpg files it had added. Command line is your best friend, as I found out.


find                 : find
/md0/moviesHD/ : look here
-name         : look for a file with the name...
'*.xml'           : anything that ends in ".xml"
-exec           : when you do, run the command...
ls -l                  : list
{}                 : ?
\;                 : END

First check which files you'll be deleting, and display them on the screen:

find /md0/moviesHD/ -name '*.xml' -exec ls -l {} \;


Only if you're sure (really!), go ahead and delete the ones just listed.


find /md0/moviesHD/ -name '*.xml' -exec rm {} \;
find /md0/moviesHD/ -name '*.jpg' -exec rm {} \;
find /md0/moviesHD/ -name '*.png' -exec rm {} \;
find /md0/moviesHD/ -name '*.nfo' -exec rm {} \;

Same thing but for my standard definition movies:

find /md0/movies/ -name '*.xml' -exec ls -l {} \;
find /md0/movies/ -name '*.xml' -exec rm {} \;
find /md0/movies/ -name '*.jpg' -exec rm {} \;
find /md0/movies/ -name '*.png' -exec rm {} \;
find /md0/movies/ -name '*.nfo' -exec rm {} \;


I quickly modified the script to remove those pesky sample movie files that had been clogging up my library too:

find /md0/movies/ -name '*sample*' -exec ls -l {} \;
find /md0/movies/ -name '*sample*' -exec rm {} \;

entry.title: Apache FDQN Error
entry.content:
When your Apache2 file server runs, it wants to know where exactly in the world it is. On the internet, this is known as a domain name, a Fully Qualified Domain Name (FDQN).

For the purposes of a LAN-side web server, our web server does not need to know it's FDQN because it does not appear on the internet, and resides only on a LAN. To this end we will stop Apache2 from panicking by letting it know that there's no need to be worried about all of that internet stuff.

We will be editing the central configuration file for Apache2, so before we make any changes let's back up the file in case we go wrong. The following uses the sudo command because we are editing file outside the jurisdiction of normal users.

cd /etc/apache2

sudo cp apache2.conf apache2.conf.bak

Now let's open up the configuration file:

sudo vim /etc/apache2/apache2.conf

Scroll all the way to the bottom and append the following to the file, taking care to replicate the capital letters:

ServerName localhost

There you are, it's that simple. Telling Apache2 that its Fully Qualified Domain name is localhost means that the domain-related functions of the server should essentially look at their own two feet. For serving web pages to the internet this would obviously not work but for our purposes it is convenient.

entry.title: Ubuntu File Server Part 12: FlexGet
entry.content:
In Part 11 of this series, we installed an configured the Deluge BitTorrent client on our Ubuntu server. With the existing large pool of storage we are able to download large files and store them on a redundant array of disks, which can tolerate the loss of any single drive. I have a growing list of TV shows (series) that I take an interest in. Keeping up with each of these is difficult using a BitTorrent client since it involves searching for and downloading the .torrent files when they become available.

Today we will be taking the next step in server automation. There are websites such as showRSS whose members automatically publish verified torrents of TV shows on RSS feeds. We will use a program called FlexGet, to monitor these feeds at regular intervals. FlexGet will check these online feeds for new torrents of our desired shows, and feed those torrents directly to our BitTorrent client Deluge, which we set up and configured last time.

Please note that configuration of FlexGet for other BitTorrent clients is rather easy but beyond the scope of this tutorial.

The two online resources used for today's activity are the great Wikipedia "list of" pages. Typing "list of [show name] episodes" into Google will usually get you to a page like this, which is a great reference as to what IS going on with a TV show. Occasionally other places may stuff up an episode or it may have been missed. The Wikipedians are pretty spot on most of the time though, so I use it as the standard.

The other resource I use is the all important source of the torrents. I found showRSS after having a search around for a while and found their free service fantastic. I didn't bother with the signup process and just use their public show feeds, such as the matching one for MythBusters.

Once you are familiar with these sites, it's time to get into the meat of this topic, having a go at FlexGet.

FlexGet is a powerful download-automation program that, when configured, can automate the downloading of media from a variety of sources. It can parse web-pages, RSS feeds and even files on your server. It can then check for the existence of the files before it downloads, and then can either download the files from the world wide web itself, or pass the files to another program such as a BitTorrent client. We will configure FlexGet to check a torrent feed website for newly published shows via RSS. FlexGet will check for the existence of the episodes on our server, and if we don't yet have it, FlexGet will download the .torrent file and load that to the top of our download queue in Deluge.

FlexGet is written in a programming language called Python. This programming language contains some convenient tools that can automate the otherwise tedious process of installing this small program on our Ubuntu server. These tools are aware of our operating system, and will download the correct files to the correct places.

Before we go any further, my thanks go to Michael Desky for his tutorial on how to install FlexGet at his blog 1000umbrellas.com. I have adapted his information below:
Firstly, we will install the python setup tools. The following command includes the installation of python, just in case it was not included in your installation.

sudo apt-get install python2.6 python-setuptools

We have used the Ubuntu package manager to install a set of tools that allows python programs to be installed in a similarly easy manner to this very process.

Next, we will install FlexGet using the easy_install tool provided in the program we just installed.

sudo easy_install flexget

You will quickly see the hassle you have avoided, gracefully pass by on screen as the easy installer downloads the necessary files and places them in the correct folders. Please note that this process was not as fast as a normal program install for a similarly sized program in Ubuntu. Grab a cup of tea, possibly Earl Grey (hot).

From here on in, you will notice an absence of sudo commands used to configure FlexGet. This is because FlexGet has been installed into your own user's directories, so that accessing and configuring FlexGet is well within the scope of your Ubuntu user's permissions.

FlexGet is configured by a series of files that inhabit in your own home directory. After the installation has finished, you will find the following files and directories populating the home of the user that installed the program.

cd /home/eagle/.flexget/

The .flexget directory is hidden from normal ls commands but is visible if hidden files and directories are requested to be shown with something like ls -la. FlexGet is configured by a series of modular files starting with config.yml. These files are written in a markup language called YAML. YAML is a bit particular with spaces and indentation, but is otherwise easy to pick up.

Unfortunately I have forgotten what the default config.yml file looks like, so pleas accept my apologies and observe the file that I myself currently have. Go ahead and run the following command to bring up the file:

vim config.yml

[Please see this page for my most up-to-date configuration file. It is an online version of my configuration.] Below is an entry from my FlexGet configuration file. It outlines all of the important markup concepts and was a working example as of the date of publication. If you want to have a tinker with the program itself, skip this section and head to the end of this post to see how to play with FlexGet itself.

feeds:
# Describes that the following content will be a list of shows.
  The Big Bang Theory:
  # The name that FlexGet will use to identify this feed and TV show
    rss: http://showrss.karmorra.info/feeds/5.rss
    # Calls the RSS plugin to parse the appended URL after the colon.
    series:
    # Tells the series plugin what the name of the show is
      - The Big Bang Theory
    preset:
    # Tells FlexGet to run the following preset commands when a new entry is found
      - tvtorrent
      # This command passes the downloaded torrent from the RSS to Deluge
      - showexists
      # This command checks for the existence of the episode on the server

presets:
# The following are a set of pre-set commands to expedite the writing of new entries in the config

  tvtorrent:
    deluge:
      content_filename: '%(series_name)s - %(series_id)s'
      movedone: /md0/series/%(series_name)s/Season %(series_season)d/
      main_file_only: yes
      queuetotop: yes
      automanaged: true

  showexists:
    exists_series: /md0/series/

Above you can see an entry to download episodes from the series "The Big Bang Theory". All of the/ components listed above can be found at the FlexGet plugin page; a great reference for the workings and syntax for all of the different bits of FlexGet.

Another great place for inspiration on configuring FlexGet is the FlexGet cookbook page. Here there is a good variety of configuration examples and options, provided by experienced users of the program and some indeed beyond my own expertise. I did however, overlook the beginner's configuration instructions found here, which are in my opinion, the best place to start.

As I found out, configuring FlexGet is a very personal experience. I found that none of the configurations I found out there quite suited me, but I learnt a great deal in writing my own from scratch and I highly recommend that you do the same. Once you are happy with yours, you too may find satisfying the level of control you have over the process.

Once you have looked at configuring FlexGet, it's time to fire up the actual program and see what it thinks of your config. For testing purposes, it's best to use FlexGet with the -t argument to ensure that no permanent changes are made. I like to use the verbosity toggles to give me as much information as possible. As such, the two following commands illustrate my main usage commands for flexget.

flexget -t -v

flexget -v

If it's not happy with your configuration file, it should tell you. As you accrue more and more TV shows, you'll want to look through your verbose test outputs to see what FlexGet is looking at to make the decisions that it does.

At this point, FlexGet is configured and just needs you to execute it, at which point it will follow your instructions (config) and check those feeds out, downloading any episodes you don't have.

Lastly, once you have created a configuration file that you and FlexGet are both happy with, it's time to automate the process using an entry on the Cron table:

sudo crontab -e

0        11-5        *      *      *      flexget --cron

Above I have configured flexget to run in quiet (daemon) mode every night so that it doesn't bother my online life during the day. Once this is done you are essentially finished and FlexGet is working. Note that the program itself only runs for about thirty seconds every hour, but this is more than enough, given the frequency of updates from the RSS feeds we have chosen.

And so we have used the Python easy_install command to install FlexGet. We have learnt a bit about YAML and created a configuration file that pulls torrent files from the RSS feeds of a website called showRSS. We have also configured FlexGet to run all night to make sure that we are up-to-date on our TV shows every morning. The only thing that doesn't happen automatically is the removal of torrents from the Deluge interface, although they DO get moved to the correct directory upon completion.

entry.title: Ubuntu File Server Part 11: Deluge BitTorrent
entry.content:
In Part 10, we set up a multi-drive, redundant array with 4TB of storage space. Between then and now I populated my new array with all of my existent data, totalling around 3TB across a number of drives. The array now has 3 out of its 4TB consumed, and it will now be our task to set up the best system by which we can keep our large media collection maintained and up-to-date. The first port of call is to set up a torrent client with which we can download new content for our media collection.

I had attempted using Transmission with my server but found its lack of modularity a problem. Editting its config file was a nuicanse and there was no queueing ability built in. This second point may not have seemed like much at the time but when we begin to automatically add many torrents as I did, running 25 downloads at once really isn't very useful as you can't watch anything as the others download. The alternative to Transmission on Ubuntu seemed to be a program called Deluge. Deluge is nowhere near as nice to set up as Transmission, having no command-line interface and needing a bit more manual handling to install. Nevertheless, its ability to play ball with Flexget (a program we will look at later), as well as its much nicer web-interface and uTorrent-like interface made it the right choice for me and I recommend it to you.

As always, chances are that someone out there has already tried what you are about to do, and to this end, I found this tutorial which explained the process very well. I will outline my interpretation of the steps below:

Although the above tutorial gives some prelimenary permission and user type instructions, I went ahead and installed the deluge package straight away, readying myself for anything that might come up.

eagle@server~$: sudo apt-get install deluged deluge-webui

This command asks Ubuntu to install the Deluge Daemon (deluged), as well as the Deluge Web-User-Interface (deluge-webui). Once this process has finished we must configure Deluge for us to be able to control it remotely. To do this we will navigate to the following directory and create a file (which Deluge knows to look for) inside which a toggle is set telling deluge to begin at startup.

eagle@server~$: cd /etc/default/
eagle@server~$: sudo vim deluge-daemon

Inside this file, copy the following text and paste it into your editor.

# Configuration for /etc/init.d/deluge-daemon
# The init.d script will only run if this variable non-empty.
DELUGED_USER="eagle"
# Should we run at startup?
RUN_AT_STARTUP="YES" 

Save and close the file. As you can see, we tell Deluge which user to masquerade as when it runs, and whether to begin at startup or not. Setting your own name as the Deluge-Daemon-User makes life easier because you can edit anything that Deluge plays with and don't have to worry about adding a new user.

At this point Deluge knows it's supposed to start at system boot but we still have to create a script to do that. Other programs you may have installed, do this automatically but with Deluge we have to do this manually. Navigate to the following directory and create the following file, pasting in the contents of the file in this link.


eagle@server~$: cd /etc/init.d/
eagle@server~$: sudo vim deluge-daemon

Here copy in the contents of the above link (this one) into the file, save and then exit the file. The file is currently treated by Ubuntu as an ordinary text file, so we we need to make the script executable, such that Ubuntu can RUN the script when it runs its startup sequence.

eagle@server~$: sudo chmod a+x /etc/init.d/deluge-daemon
eagle@server~$: sudo update-rc.d deluge-daemon defaults

At this point you should be able to reboot your server and find that the Deluge Daemon starts automatically with your system. You could check the "top" command, watch the startup output of your server or simply try connecting to the web-interface.

eagle@server~$: sudo reboot now
eagle@server~$: top 

Take a look around for your Deluge Daemon. In my case it worked (of course). The structure of Deluge is that a Daemon program runs in the background. Your installation also included a small website called the web-interface. When you browse to this web page (which need not necessarily be on your server) you will select a Daemon with which to connect. The Web-Interface will then connect through to the Daemon process running on the server and act as an interface for you.

So in essence, you could connect to your web-interface on Server A, and then when prompted by that page, connect that web-interface to a Daemon process on Server B. This might be useful if you have a web-server or some such complication, but for us it simply illustrates the structure of the program.

The Web Interface is accessed by port 8112 on your server via a web browser. Try the following address in your web browser (which I hope is Chrome.):

http://server:8112 

Here, you might be prompted for a Daemon to connect to. The Daemon process is running on the same machine as the web-interface, so you should see an entry called 127.0.0.1 (localhost) which is the program we just installed. I recommend setting all of your settings via the web interface. Don't worry about the command line anymore for your torrents.

The only quirk with the Web-Interface is that sometimes in order for the settings to stick, you need to reopen the settings popup and navigate straight to the desired tab.

Try some torrents out, perhaps even a legit one to start off with. And so we have successfully installed and configured both the Daemon and the WebUI for the Deluge torrent program. In Part 12 of our series we will set up additional programs to feed torrents and other media to our hungry beast (not to be confused with Hungry Beast) of a server, with plenty of free, failure tolerant space.

In Part 12 of this series, we will configure a program to automate the timely downloading of TV shows to our server through our newly configured Deluge BitTorrent client.
