entry.title: Ubuntu File Server Part 10: RAID5
entry.content:
In Part 9 our our series, we looked at how to share your Ubuntu directories with Windows computers and other devices. This was all just a bit of practice, that can be applied again once we do today's task. This is the real nitty gritty of our server and will make the new backbone of what we do.

Today we will be configuring a group of 3 WD hard drives of capacity 2TB. I purchased two more of these after using one as a dump drive for a while. What drove me toward a RAID configuration was firstly, curiosity, and secondly, the ability to pool together my storage space. I was quite sick of moving files around my hard drives as directories grew and shrank. I very much wanted a way to create a large, super-drive with a large proportion of the sum of all of the drives' storage space. They say that you don't start looking at backup/redundancy until you lose your first set of data. I thought I'd buck the trend and give RAID a go to solve both problems.

Ideally I could have set up a ZFS zpool of all of my drives. Unfortunately ZFS, which began on Solaris and moved over to OpenSolaris, has yet to be well optimised for the Linux operating system. ZFS was born outside the Linux world and so is in the process of being ported over to Linux. That means that the code would not be as easy to use and not as well supported as the native hard drive management tools. I had considered a distribution such as FreeNAS but the modularity of Ubuntu Server as well as it's easy learning curve made that decision for me. Also, as ZFS is a port from BSD to Linux, Samba is a port from Linux to BSD, so network file transmission would not be good. This defeats the purpose of a fast drive array. All that, meant that I had to stick (for performance's sake) to Ubuntu's hard drive management tools.

To begin a RAID of drives you must first choose the type (known commonly as 'level') of RAID you want to go for. The Wikipedia Page on standard RAID levels really is quite poor, but does give the necessary information for us to proceed. Given three drives and my desire for some redundancy, I chose RAID 5. This meant that I had (N-1)*(Smallest Drive Size) space. (3-1)*2TB = 4TB so my RAID5 array would have 4TB of usable space, having consumed 6TB of data. This is OK by me, since my 3x1TB drives constituted my entire loot collection. This meant that I would have an extra 1TB up my sleeve, possible performance increases and redundancy to boot.

Before we begin playing with our drives, we will want to unmount them so that their partitions can be safely played with. Creating a RAID array is destructive and you will lose any data you had on your drives, so go through them and check that you don't have anything important on them. Then go ahead an umount each of them:

eagle@server~$: sudo umount /dev/sdb1
eagle@server~$: sudo umount /dev/sdd1

This RAID stuff all sounded great on paper but it was time to put my theory to the test and actually have a go. First thing to do is to attach all of the drives physically and boot your server. Use our favourite parted to check out that all drives are attached.

eagle@server~$: sudo parted
(parted) print devices

Here we should be able to see all of our drives listed. You can see 3 lots of 2TB drives ready to go.

An important note before going ahead. We will be constructing the RAID from partitions on the drives. It is possible to partition a drive into three segments and then construct a RAID 5. The problem with this, apart from processing overhead, is that you achieve none of the benefits of the REDUNDANT array of DISKS. Hence the rule of thumb is to always create RAID arrays out of whole-drive-partitions.

(parted) select /dev/sdb
(parted) print
Using /dev/sdc
(parted) print
Model: ATA WDC WD20EARS-00M (scsi)
Disk /dev/sdc: 2000GB
Sector size (logical/physical): 512B/512B
Partition Table: gpt
Number Start End Size File system Name Flags

1 1049kB 2000GB 2000GB ext4 primary
(parted) rm 1
(parted) mkpart primary ext4 1 -1
(parted) select /dev/sdc
(parted) print
Model: ATA WDC WD20EARS-00M (scsi)
Disk /dev/sdc: 2000GB
Sector size (logical/physical): 512B/512B
Partition Table: gpt
Number Start End Size File system Name Flags

1 1049kB 2000GB 2000GB ext4 primary
(parted) rm 1
(parted) mkpart primary ext4 1 -1
(parted) select /dev/sdd
(parted) print
Model: ATA WDC WD20EARS-00M (scsi)
Disk /dev/sdc: 2000GB
Sector size (logical/physical): 512B/512B
Partition Table: gpt
Number Start End Size File system Name Flags

1 1049kB 2000GB 2000GB ext4 primary
(parted) rm 1
(parted) mkpart primary ext4 1 -1
(parted) quit

Above, we selected each of the three 2TB drives and performed the following operations. Note that so far, we are performing a task similar to Part 7 of my Ubuntu File Server series. We selected the drive, printed a list of all its partitions (and other information) and then removed all of the partitions. In this case each drive had just one partition. We then created a new partition with the marker "ext4" going from block number 1 to the last block (block number -1). Doing so ensures that our partition blocks of size 4096 bytes, match with the physical hard drive sectors of size 4096 bytes. This means that if Ubuntu asks to access sector 100 on our partition, the hard drive head simply needs to access sector 101. This is opposed to the scenario where they don't match up. Then if Ubuntu asked to read block 100, the hard drive head might need to access sectors 102 and 103 since partition block 100 spans some of sector 102 an some of sector 3. Given the number of block reads and writes, and the number of corresponding sector reads and writes, if our blocks and sectors didn't align we could potentially double the work on the hard drive has to do!

At this point, each of our three 2TB drives (sdb, sdc and sdd) has a whole-drive-partition (sdb1, sdc1 and sdd1) whose block size and position matches the sectors on the drive.

Now to the creation of our new beast, the RAID 5 array! For this part of the process I found an absolutely fantastic blog post by fellow Blogger Jonny, at his site here. He uses a GUI version of parted but otherwise, he does it all by command line, and it's a great reference. He explains command line arguments better than I do, but I'll try and give my own interpretation of the idea here.

We will be using a package called mdadm, which is short for Multi Drive ADMinistrator. It is a very popular tool created for linux that is today the bread and butter of RAID arrays. Jonny provides us with a great stencil for a terminal command, which I've modified to suit my own setup. It is shown below:

eagle@server~$: sudo mdadm --create --verbose /dev/md0 --level=5 --raid-devices=3 /dev/sdb1 /dev/sdc1 /dev/sdd1

This sets mdadm off, creating the array from our new partitons. One of the first things it does is "recover" the array until it has calculated the parity of each block in the array. Even though the drives are empty, mdadm is a bit pedantic and does bitwise operations on each block. We'll want to watch this closely and we will not want to do anything to our array until the process is finished. I tried formatting the new partition as it was being recovered and the two brought by system to a stalemate of windowsy time estimates. Thanks again to Jonny, we will use the following command to watch the array recover itself:

eagle@server~$: sudo watch cat /proc/mdstat

At this point I will assume your system has completed the recovery of the array and that the above command now shows an array in what is known as "clean" mode. This is how it should be!

We have created our array, but the mdadm daemon program still doesn't know how to interact with the array, so we will create a small file to explain to the mdadm daemon, what our array is all about and how to load it up when we boot.

eagle@server~$: cd /etc/mdadm
eagle@server~$: sudo cp mdadm.conf mdadm.conf.bak
eagle@server~$: sudo echo "DEVICE partitions" > /etc/mdadm/mdadm.conf
eagle@server~$: sudo mdadm --detail -- >> /etc/mdadm/mdadm.conf

Go ahead and check out the file we just wrote to. You can see a rather verbose explanation of how the new array works. We're done here, and the lasts steps are simply to create a file system on the new partition and then to configure our system to automatically mount the new patition at boot time.

Ubuntu will have named your new array partition as "md0." This is a sort of short-hand for Multi Drive [partition] 0. Ubuntu uses 0-base indexes for this, as opposed to the 1-base index you will have seen for traditional drives and formats back in Part 7. 

Just like we did back there, we are going to furnish our new parition with a file system. I chose to continue with ext4, in light of stability issues with BTRFS at the moment. BTRFS is maturing rapidly, but sudden power outages can still damage the file system. Given my lack of UPS, this was a deal breaker. Anyway, I have heard that it is possible to convert an ext4 file system to BTRFS, so I may yet to that at a later date.

In the mean time, here is the command to populate the multi-drive partition with ext4. Given the enormous nature of the parition, setting aside 5% for the super-block would put a significant dent in our storage space. Hence the argument -m1 was used to restrict the super-block to just 1% of the filesystem space, which is still more than enough.
I believe that the super-block is mainly used as some sort of filesystem-based backup in case something goes wrong. Might want to find out more about this, but it's certainly safe to use a smaller value for this super-block.

eagle@server~$: sudo mkfs.ext4 -m1 /dev/md0


This will take a while, but nowhere near as long as the array-recover took. Grab a cup of tea. Once this is done, we'll create a mount point for the newly formatted paritition on our root filesystem.Although confusing to some people, I like to mount my partitions in the root directory in similarly named directories. To this effect I create a directory there.

eagle@server~$: sudo mkdir /md0

After this, we'll want Ubuntu to automatically mount the new filesystem at boot, so we'll head back to the fstab file and add our new partition to the list. You will want to remove any mention of the used-drives elsewhere on this drive. For example, I had had my older 2TB drive listed to be mounted on its own at boot. Unmounting all of the drives removed this problem temporily but Ubuntu would have tried to mount its partition at the next boot becaue my instructions in fstab still stood. Although I doubt this would stop mdadm from doing the righ thing, it's best to remove it or at least comment it out to avoid confusion.

eagle@server~$: cd /etc/
eagle@server~$: sudo vim fstab

/dev/md0 /md0 ext4 defaults 0 0

The Wiki page for fstab is, unlike its RAID levels counterpart, very useful. The first few parts are pretty straight forward; which partition to mount, where to mount it. In the next part, although we could tell fstab to mount it no matter what file system is being used, I have decided to tell fstab that it should be looking for an ext4 file system. This can be detected automatically by setting the String to "auto". "Defaults" indicates that there are no special options associated with this mount and to treat the mount as a normal partition. The two integers at the end caught my attention and eluded me for a while. From the wikipedia page, I can now say that the first integer inicates how often the mount should be backed up. Since this is my newly stratospheric file system and it IS effectively my backup, I set this to 0, telling fstab not to back it up ever. The second integer tells the fstab the order in which to run a fsck (file system checker) on boot. In retrospect I really should have set this to 2. The Wiki for fstab says to set this value to 1 for the root file system and then 2 for any after that. To tell Ubuntu not to check the file system could bite me back in the future, so I changed this to 2. If Ubuntu detects any abnormalities in the file system at boot, it will attempt to fix them instead of ignoring them as it would if this value were set to 0.

It is now time to reboot your sytem. This will cause the following events: mdadm will stop the array, the system will reboot, mdadm will start the array again, fstab will find the functioning array, mount it to where we said and then check it for any errors. This will result in the /md0 directory now representing the tip of your new 4TB RAID5 array.

For fun you could run a "df -h" command to see how your new array looks, and it looks great!

One last thing, and this is important! So far, we have ignored the function of the power button on our new server. It was previously unresponsive, and only responded to the five-second-hold; a hard power off. This has the capacity to damage our array. David at his Bad Ass Blog quotes effectively the scenario where you may lose data or partition space. Basically if you write data to the array but lose power before the array has a chance of calculating the parity block, the data and its parity will forever mismatch and give incorrect data back from this now corrupt block.

Given that my needs are not that great, I figure that a power outage is unlikely enough that the number of write-holes in my array should remain quite low. I did, however, want to remove any other scenarios of this happening, the most obvious of these being trying to shut down the server without SSH access. Previously I'd simply hold down the power button until it turned off, but this could damage the array.

Thankfully the fix is easy, installation of a certain package can make Ubuntu aware of the power button press and allow itself to shut down gracefully with enough time for the raid-management-daemon to finish what it was doing. The package is called acpid and it fixes the problem in one, short, easy step:

eagle@server~$: sudo apt-get install acpid

At this point, pulling out the power wouldn't be too healthy for our system but at the same time not a catastrophe as it might be with BTRFS (at the time of writing). Check for success by shutting down with a momentary press of your power button. Reboot and try to access a file on your array-parition. This was succesful for me and I called it a day, smiling gleefully at the thought of what I had: a 4TB striped array capable fo surviving the loss of any 1 of the 3 drives. It can be expanded and even upgraded into a RAID6 if I'm feeling data-vulnerable.

I moved all of my three 1TB drives' contents over to my new array. It took a while and my raid drives showed write-patterns that showed that something very clever was going on.

In Part 11 we will install a BitTorrent client to enable us to download new files to our RAID array.

entry.title: Ubuntu File Server Part 9: Windows Filesharing
entry.content:
In Part 8 we populated a hard drive with some data from another, Windows formatted hard drive. In this part we will be looking at making the data of our newly populated hard drive available to windows users over the network. A reference for this guide can be found at the trusty Ubuntu Server Guide section on serving files.

Our first port of call is to install the samba package. Samba is a package that allows Ubuntu to connect and be connected to by Windows machines exploring their network through Windows Explorer. The protocol used is called SMB (Server Message Block) and also known as CIFS (Common Internet File System.)

eagle@server:~$  sudo apt-get install samba

Once we've installed Samba our server is ready to start interacting with windows computer. Our machine, being a server, will predominantly want to serve files on local hard drives over the network using SMB. Installation of the Samba package does give us the ability to browse other machines and interact with their files, however this is outside the scope of this part of the guide.

The Samba package consists of a few things. There is a command-line-program to interact with other machines using SMB but more importantly a Samba daemon (a constantly-running background process.) This Samba daemon is the process that will respond to the browsing requests of other computers using SMB and serve the files to them over the same protocol. As with all things Ubuntu, there is a configuration file that controls the daemon's behaviour. Below we browse to it and edit it after first backing it up.

eagle@server:~$ cd /etc/samba
eagle@server:~$ sudo cp smb.conf smb.conf.bak
eagle@server:~$ sudo vim smb.conf

Here we will edit the file as shown. Here we will configure a large number of settings. I used this incredibly helpful guide from calomel.org to figure it all out.

[global]
        #only bind to the default ip of an interface
        bind interface only = yes
        # time in minutes until samba will consider an idle connection dead
        deadtime = 15
        # netbios broadcasts are not needed for windows shares but perhaps for wdtv
        disable netbios = no
        # do not lookup with a dns server any unregistered netbios names
        dns proxy = yes
        # use the wins protocol
        wins support = yes
        # this means that samba will take over as the domain master, no matter what the windows machines say
        domain master = yes
        # allow guest access to the shares, i.e. without a login
        # this is synonimous with public = ok
        guest ok = yes
        # all machines accessing the shares will be guests
        guest only = yes
        # tells samba which interface(s) to bind to
        interfaces = eth0
        # no windows user should ever try to log in with the names:
        invalid users = admin_user root
        # no printers used on this server so disable the feature to prevent confusion
        load printers = no
        # goes with load printers as we do not have any printers on this server
        printable = no
        # limits the number of clients samba will allow access from
        max connections = 10
        # the name in the parenthises that windows clients will see
        netbios name = server
        # this says that the samba server will always win the vote for master server on a windows network
        preferred master = yes
        # the name of this computer that windows clients will se
        server string = Server
        # speed optimisations for windows computers
        # TCP_NODELAY may well be redundant with newer versions of samba
        # https://calomel.org/samba_optimize.html
        socket options = TCP_NODELAY IPTOS_LOWDELAY SO_RCVBUF=65536 SO_SNDBUF=65536 SO_KEEPALIVE
        # disabled to speed up samba
        # strict syncing is used if you are paranoid about data loss but problem not usually seen
        strict sync = no
        sync always = no
        # the workgroup that this computer will appear to be a part of to a windows machine
        workgroup = WORKGROUP
        # SEEMS TO CAUSE MAGIC SUCCESS
        security = share
        # says we are going to log to the syslog facility
        syslog = 1
        # means that only the syslog facility will be receiving logs from samba
        syslog only = yes
        # enable browsing of the shares
        browseable = yes
        # globally force forbidding of changes to the shares
        writeable = no
        # possibly reduntant, don't know what this does
        available = yes

[Game Files]
        path = /md0/gamefiles

[Movies SD]
        path = /md0/movies

[Movies HD]
        path = /md0/moviesHD

[Music]
        path = /md0/music

[Operating Systems]
        path = /md0/operatingSystems

[Programs]
        path = /md0/programs

[Wallpaper]
        path = /md0/wallpaper

EDIT: To see my most up-to-date configuration for Samba, see this link to the relevant Github repository, by myself. That said, all you need to know is shown above.

Samba can be a hit hit and miss, depending on what you are trying to avail your content to. The above config was what I needed for my Windows 7 machine to be able to access the share, as well as my WDTV-LIVE media box.


Also note my copious commenting. I will certainly forget the bits and pieces so I put reminders in for myself. In the above example I have made the directory /2tb/1tb-movies/Movies available publicly with read-only access to anyone who can browse to the server.

There is one final step to complete before we can successfully browse to the share from our Windows computer. If you were to try now (after applying settings by restarting Daemon) you would find that you haven't the necessary permissions to access the folder. The reason for this is that Samba will respect Ubuntu's UNIX-style file and group permissions.

It pays to do your homework when it comes to these permissions as you can muck things up and get quite confused if you set the wrong permissions and groups to a file or directory. I probably don't know as much as I should, and I simply followed the Ubuntu Server Guide's tutorial including the steps below, which makes the directory accessible from Windows Explorer. My go-to guide for Linux file permissions is this page. In short, the following integers are notable:

4 = read
2 = write
1 = execute

There are three types of permissions you need to allow for a file or directory in Linux. The owner's permissions, the group-owner's permissions and the permissions of everyone else. You simply add the integers to give the permissions you'd like.

For example, 777 will give, the owner, group and everyone else, full read, write and execute permission to the file. 755 will give write permissions to the owner, but only read and execute permissions to the group and everyone else.

We then use chown to set the group, although here my file permissions don't necessarily make good use of group file permissions.

eagle@server:~$ /2tb/1tb-movies
eagle@server:~$ sudo chown -R eagle.eagle Movies
eagle@server:~$ sudo chmod -R 755 Movies

In the above code, I browsed to the folder that I had asked Samba to share. Then I assigned no-owner and no-group-owners to all files and folders recursively. Now that we have modified Samba's configuration and matched the directory permissions in Ubuntu it's time to restart the Samba daemon to take up the new settings and hopefully we will then be able to see the folder from our Windows comptuer.

eagle@server:~$ sudo restart smbd
eagle@server:~$ sudo restart nmdb

In Part 10, we will redefine our server by creating a redundant array of disks to store all of our data.

link.title: Ubuntu File Server Part 9: Windows Filesharing

entry.title: Ubuntu File Server Part 8: File Copying
entry.content:
In Part 7 we formatted a new 2TB hard drive with the linux Ext4 file system. What good is an empty hard drive though, so in this part we will copy some files from a very full, windows formatted 1TB drive over to our newly formatted drive.

Windows formats its drives in NTFS by default, and the source drive in question has been formatted in this way. After we have installed the drive on our machine we'll boot up and configure Ubuntu to use the drive.

In windows, the drive gets mounted to the root file directory. When you open My Computer you'll see all of the hard drives listed there. Ubuntu is able to mount the hard drive not only there but onto any folder in the directory tree. For example your USB drive can be mounted onto your My Documents folder, so that when you browse there you'll see the contents of the USB drive.

First we'll consult our trusty fdisk command to list all of our hard drives and find out which one is the new one.

eagle@server:~$ sudo fdisk -l | grep /dev/sd
Disk /dev/dm-0 doesn't contain a valid partition table
Disk /dev/dm-1 doesn't contain a valid partition table
Disk /dev/sda: 80.0 GB, 80026361856 bytes
/dev/sda1 * 1 32 248832 83 Linux
/dev/sda2 32 9730 77899777 5 Extended
/dev/sda5 32 9730 77899776 8e Linux LVM
Disk /dev/sdc: 2000.4 GB, 2000398934016 bytes
/dev/sdc1 1 243202 1953514583+ ee GPT
Disk /dev/sdb: 1000.2 GB, 1000204886016 bytes
/dev/sdb1 * 1 121602 976759808 7 HPFS/NTFS

We can see /dev/sdc as the drive we formatted in Part 7 and we can see /dev/sdc is out new 1TB drive. We can also see below the highlighted line that the drive has one partition in NTFS. In the previous part we told Ubuntu to automatically mount our 2TB drive. Our new 1TB drive, however, has not been automatically mounted so we will do this manually. Step 1 is to create a folder for the new mount point. Step 2 is to mount the drive.

eagle@server:~$ cd /
eagle@server:/$ sudo mkdir 1tb

This creates a directory on the root of the directory tree called 1tb. Now we'll mount the drive's partition (as seen in fdisk -l) onto our new folder.

eagle@server:/$ sudo mount /dev/sdb1 /1tb

At this point if we browse to the folder /1tb/ we will see the contents of the 1TB drive that we just mounted. At this point we have 2 drives mounted, one automatically and the other one manually. We want to copy some files over from the 1TB drive to the 2TB drive. To do this we will use the fantastic rsync command.

This powerful command is definitely one you'll want to know back to front on a per-parameter basis before you go ahead and use it. Thankfully rsync doesn't delete nor move files, it only copies, but you'll still want to proceed with caution. First we'll use the -n toggle to do a dry run and see the output of the command. I like to use rsync in its more verbose form to give me more feedback.

eagle@server:~$ cd /1tb
eagle@server:/1tb$ sudo rsync -ahnvv * /2tb/1tb-movies/

This command will spit out a whole lot of directories and files that rsync would copy if we were not doing a dry run. Once you've gone over this output and are happy with it, you can go ahead and remove the -n toggle.

eagle@server:/1tb$ sudo rsync -ahvv * /2tb/1tb-movies/

Once you're finished with the copy you can always double check the copy by running the command again. The archive command was used because it will cause rsync to copy recursively and mirror the original directory structure and permissions exactly.

So now we have copied the contents of an NTFS formatted Windows drive over to our newly formatted and partitioned linux 2TB drive. In Part 9 we will configure our Ubuntu Server to interact with Windows machines and be able to serve its files to them.

entry.title: Ubuntu File Server Part 7: Drive Formatting
entry.content:
In Part 6 we made ourselves some pretty graphs to show us how cool our server is. In this part we will be learning how to format a 2TB SATA hard drive.

The knowledge for this came predominantly from three sources. Firstly and most relevantly is this excellent post on how to format a drive larger than 2TB. Supporting information was taken from this blog post with regard to how the drive alignment works. Finally this article from IBM was a good read on what exactly the drive alignment and GPT issue is, with these large new drives on the market. For the most part, however, we will implement this knowledge but it won't be explained in too much detail as it's not really necessary in order to get the drive working.

Firstly we'll want to install our new hard drive on the server machine and reboot our server. Once we have logged into our terminal session we will look for and format the new drive. First we enter the parted program, which is the program we use to play with disks and paritions.


eagle@server:~$ sudo parted
GNU Parted 2.3
Using /dev/sda
Welcome to GNU Parted! Type 'help' to view a list of commands.
(parted)

Now we are inside the parted command prompt. Normal commands don't do anything here and you have to enter commands specific to parted. First we'll list all the drives installed:


(parted) print devices
/dev/sda (80.0GB)
/dev/sdb (1000GB)
/dev/sdc (2000GB)
/dev/sdd (1000GB)
/dev/mapper/server-swap_1 (3297MB)
/dev/mapper/server-root (76.5GB)


We can see from this printout that we have four physical hard drives installed. Ubuntu has named them sda, sdb, sdc and sdd. Ubuntu will name their partitions numerically. For example sda will have partitions sda1, sda2, sda3, etc.

So we pick out the name of the drive we'd like to partition, in this case sdc. You can always type help to find out what you can do, and quit if you've had enough. Next we will select our newly installed disk:

(parted) select /dev/sdc
Using /dev/sdc
(parted) print
Model: ATA WDC WD20EARS-00M (scsi)
Disk /dev/sdc: 2000GB
Sector size (logical/physical): 512B/512B
Partition Table: gpt

Number Start End Size File system Name Flags
1 1049kB 2000GB 2000GB ext4 primary

If you find that using the print command gives the error "unrecognized disk label" you need to run the following command after selecting the drive:

(parted) mklabel gpt

After selecting our new drive I have used the print command to display the existing partitions on the drive. In this case I have performed this operation before and the end result is already visible. Note the numbered partition 1 listed in the table at the bottom.

Before we create a new partition we will remove any old ones. If your disk has no partitions go ahead and skip this step. We do this by using the remove command and specifying the number of the partition(s) we saw above, in this case number one:

(parted) rm 1
(parted) print
Model: ATA WDC WD20EARS-00M (scsi)
Disk /dev/sdc: 2000GB
Sector size (logical/physical): 512B/512B
Partition Table: gpt

Number Start End Size File system Name Flags

And just as quickly the partition is gone. Now we have the opportunity to create a new partition of our choice. We will use the ext4 file system and begin from the second MB of space on the drive (starting at position 1) and we will end at -1 (keyword for the end of the drive).

(parted) mkpart primary ext4 1 -1
(parted) print
Model: ATA WDC WD20EARS-00M (scsi)
Disk /dev/sdc: 2000GB
Sector size (logical/physical): 512B/512B
Partition Table: gpt

Number Start End Size File system Name Flags
1 1049kB 2000GB 2000GB ext4 primary

We then used the print command to see our new partition. Success! Now that we have created the partition we can exit parted and format the drive. Don't worry about fstab, we'll get to that later.

(parted) quit
Information: You may need to update /etc/fstab.

eagle@server:~$ sudo mkfs.ext4 -m1 /dev/sdc1
mke2fs 1.41.12 (17-May-2010)
Filesystem label=
OS type: Linux
Block size=4096 (log=2)
Fragment size=4096 (log=2)
Stride=0 blocks, Stripe width=0 blocks
122101760 inodes, 488378368 blocks
4883783 blocks (1.00%) reserved for the super user
First data block=0
Maximum filesystem blocks=4294967296
14905 block groups
32768 blocks per group, 32768 fragments per group
8192 inodes per group
Superblock backups stored on blocks:
32768, 98304, 163840, 229376, 294912, 819200, 884736, 1605632, 2654208,
4096000, 7962624, 11239424, 20480000, 23887872, 71663616, 78675968,
102400000, 214990848


Writing inode tables: 997/14905

OK, so here we have quit out of parted and then used the make-file-system (mkfs) program to create an ext4 formatting on the drive and call the partition sdc1. The -m1 toggle tells the drive to use only 1% of its  space for the backup superblock. A nuance used to rescue data if things go wrong. On a hard drive this size 1% clearly already gives plenty of superblock backups as shown  by the list of locations in the bottom table of the above terminal printout.

This process will take time, so grab a cup of coffee and sit back while the drive gets formatted.

Once the drive is formatted it's time to create a mount point for it. For those who might care, see this Wikipedia article on why I use the name disk instead of disk when creating a mount point for our drive's partition. Before we can make the drive available to Ubuntu (mounted) we must specify a location where we will mount it. Ubuntu treats the mount point as just another directory, so unlike Windows you can mount a partition anywhere in the directory tree (or just about, anyway.) To this effect we will create a mount point called disk1 in the root directory of our Ubuntu server:

eagle@server:~$ cd /
eagle@server:/$ mkdir sdc1

If you want to mount the drive right now, go ahead (use mount and umount to mount and unmount the partition.) We will instead configure Ubuntu to mount it upon booting so that we don't have to think about it again. Ubuntu keeps its drive configuration file, called fstab in the standard /etc/ directory and we'll edit it after backing it up:

eagle@server:/$ cd /etc/
eagle@server:/etc$ sudo cp fstab fstab.bak
eagle@server:/etc$ sudo vim fstab
# /etc/fstab: static file system information.
#
# Use 'blkid -o value -s UUID' to print the universally unique identifier
# for a device; this may be used with UUID= as a more robust way to name
# devices that works even if disks are added and removed. See fstab(5).
#
# <file system> <mount point> <type> <options> <dump> <pass>
proc /proc proc nodev,noexec,nosuid 0 0
/dev/mapper/server-root / ext4 errors=remount-ro 0 1
# /boot was on /dev/sda1 during installation
UUID=51e6e1bc-8b50-4f4a-bfc8-65df99606a76 /boot ext2 defaults 0 2
/dev/mapper/server-swap_1 none swap sw 0 0
# /dev/scd0 /media/floppy0 auto rw,user,noauto,exec,utf8 0 0
/dev/sdc1 /sdc1 ext4 defaults 0 0
 You can see where we have told the configuration file which partition to mount, where to mount it, what kind of partition it is and some default values telling Ubuntu to treat it like any other drive. We're just a reboot away from our new drive being mounted and ready to go:

eagle@server:~$ sudo reboot now

Browsing to /disk1, you will now find an empty drive ready and rearing to go. Thus we have successfully wiped any existing, created a new filesystem and formatted our new drive. We have told Ubuntu 10.10 Server x64 to automatically mount it on boot and so the drive is fully configured.

In Part 8 we will populate the new drive with some files from another hard drive.

entry.title: Ubuntu File Server Part 5: Internet Time
entry.content:
In Part 4 we configured Ubuntu to allow remote terminal access and we changed the source of the server's package downloads. In this part we will configure Ubuntu to keep its system time up to date in order to keep everything (log files in particular,) accurate.

The simplest way to keep Ubuntu's system time up-to-date is to manually initiate an update. This is shown below and is a good place to start:

eagle@server:~$ sudo ntpdate -s pool.ntp.org

This command asks the ntp program to poll the site ntp.org for the correct time.

But we want this to happen automatically and not manually. In order to do this we install the Network Time Protocol Daemon. Thanks to this how-to tutorial and the Ubuntu Server Guide's section on this topic we will configure this program to keep our server in correct time. Firstly we will install the package:

eagle@server:~$ sudo apt-get install ntp

Then we will edit its configuration file after first backing it up. If your ntp.conf file does not exist feel free to create it. The following commands assume its existence:

eagle@server:~$ cd /etc/
eagle@server:~$ sudo cp ntp.conf ntp.conf.bak
eagle@server:~$ sudo vim ntp.conf
driftfile /var/lib/ntp/ntp.drift
# Comments omitted
statistics loopstats peerstats clockstats
filegen loopstats file loopstats type day enable
filegen peerstats file peerstats type day enable
filegen clockstats file clockstats type day enable
# You do need to talk to an NTP server or two (or three).
server ntp.ubuntu.com
server pool.ntp.org
# Comments omitted
restrict -4 default kod notrap nomodify nopeer noquery
restrict -6 default kod notrap nomodify nopeer noquery
# Local users may interrogate the ntp server more closely.
restrict 127.0.0.1
restrict ::1
Now we have configured our NTP Daemon to look at pool.ntp.org for network time updates. Having the Daemon active means that the program will remain active in the background and keep our time in sync with internet time. To make the NTPD take the changed configuration we will restart its process:

eagle@server:~$ sudo /etc/init.d/ntp restart

Once the process has been restarted we want to check that our NTP Daemon is succesfully keeping our time in sync. We do this via the following commands which lists the peers (hence -p) with  which our NTP Daemon has communicated:


eagle@server:~$ ntpq -p
     remote           refid      st t when poll reach   delay   offset  jitter
==============================================================================
*europium.canoni 193.79.237.14    2 u   44   64  377  331.664  -12.677   4.039
+ntp.central-dat 203.12.160.2     3 u   48   64  377   35.065    7.969   2.012

On writing this post I found a great explanation of what is meant by the output of this command. I recommend it if you'd like to know more about this command.


So now we have configured our Ubuntu Server with internet time and installed the NTPD package to automate this process. In Part 6 we will install some more packages to show us some pretty graphs to show us how much hard work our new server will be doing.

entry.title: Ubuntu File Server Part 6: Stats and Graphs
entry.content:
In Part 5 we set up out Ubuntu 10.10 Server x64 to automatically synchronise itself with the time servers on the internet. Before we get into the file systems and formatting of hard drives it's time to make sure all our hard work will result in, at least some pretty graphs. You gots to have graphs!

Our server will collect system statistics using a program called Munin and then serve them over a webserver: Apache2. First things first we'll install the web server that Munin will use to display its stats.

eagle@server:~$ sudo apt-get install apache2

And then our Munin program. For this part of our series I used this guide from Ubuntu Geek.

eagle@server:~$ sudo apt-get install munin munin-node

At this point the Munin program will begin gathering system statistics and serving them through the Apache server. The only limitation is that by default, Munin is configured to only allow browsers from its own computer to see its statistics. Statistics are read-only so there's very little danger in allowing anyone on your network to view them. To this effect we will copy Munin's Apache configuration file (after backing it up) to allow access from all IPs.

eagle@server:~$ cd /etc/munin
eagle@server:/etc/munin$ sudo cp apache.conf apache.conf.bak
eagle@server:/etc/munin$ sudo vim apache.conf
Alias /munin /var/cache/munin/www
          <Directory /var/cache/munin/www>
          Order allow,deny
          #Allow from localhost 127.0.0.0/8 ::1
          Allow from all
          Options None
          # You'll see a whole bunch of descriptive comments here.
          # I've omitted them for clarity's sake.
          <IfModule mod_expires.c>
                    ExpiresActive On
                    ExpiresDefault M310
          </IfModule>
</Directory>
You can see above that we have commented out the default rule allowing access only from the host computer, and replaced it with a rule allowing access from any computer.

Now it's just up to us to reboot the web server so that it can take up the new configuration and then go look at our graphs.

eagle@server:~$ sudo /etc/init.d/apache2 restart

At this point we just point our browser to the server and append /munin to the address. In my case:

http://192.168.1.200/munin/

And we can see some very empty graphs. Munin takes a while to populate the graphs as they are daily and weekly scaled. Take a look in a few hours or days and see what's changed!


If you would like to add plug-ins to Munin, the following guide, although specific, deals with how to make the necessary hard links and do the necessary configuration.


To run through it briefly:


Copy the link address from download page in the Munin plugin exchange. Then paste it into the following commands:


eagle@server:~$ cd /usr/share/munin/plugins/
eagle@server:/usr/share/munin/plugins$ sudo wget http://exchange.munin-monitoring.org/plugins/network-usage/version/1/download
eagle@server:/usr/share/munin/plugins$ sudo mv download bandwidth
eagle@server:/usr/share/munin/plugins$ sudo chown root.root bandwidth
eagle@server:/usr/share/munin/plugins$ sudo chmod 755 bandwidth
eagle@server:/usr/share/munin/plugins$ sudo ln -s /usr/share/munin/plugins/bandwidth /etc/munin/plugins/bandwidth

That should do it, Munin should take up the new plugin on its next refresh. If you find Munin is not refreshing, remove the file from the /etc/munin/plugins directory, wait for Munin to refresh correctly and then try again.

Log files for munin can be found in /var/log/munin/. Check these out for details of any misbehaving plugins.

We have now successfully configured our Ubuntu Server to gather system statistics using the Munin statistics program and to then serve them to any IP over HTTP using the Apache2 web server. In Part 7 we will look at installing and configuring a 2TB hard drive and formatting it in ext4.

link.title: Ubuntu File Server Part 6: Stats and Graphs

entry.title: Ubuntu File Server Part 4: Remote Control and Mirrors
entry.content:
In Part 3 of this series we configured our Ubuntu server to connect to the internet using a wireless adapter. One of the most useful benefits of having our server connected to the internet is that there is the prospect of logging into its command line interface remotely. I run Windows 7 Professional on my gaming machine and so I often use the program PuTTY, an SSH client for windows that can login to our Ubuntu server remotely and provide all of the same features as if I was controlling the server remotely.

One warning: Since we are connecting and controlling the server through a network connection we will want to be extra careful when playing with network settings. I have bungled my network settings enough times, and had to plug a monitor and keyboard back into my server machine in order to reconfigure the network settings to that I could SSH in.

Now that our Ubuntu server is connected to the internet we will be wanting to download and install packages to increase its functionality. Ubuntu pulls pre-compiled programs from online mirors for updates and manual program installs. Before we can install packages we must let Ubuntu update the list of packages it can install, and we do this by letting it synchronise with an online mirror. This is done via the following command:

eagle@server:~$ sudo apt-get update

This command is quite verbose; it spits out a lot of garbage letting you know what it's up to. This may take a while on first install and so we'll leave it until its finished. Now Ubuntu will have a local list of packages it can install. When called to do so, it will pull the necessary package from the mirror of our choice (defaulted to a public mirror).

Next we'll want to enable remote access to our server and we will do this by installing a package as follows. This package will allow me to login securely to my server using a program like PuTTY or using the ssh command from any other terminal. (Ubuntu's own tutorial here).

eagle@server:~$ sudo apt-get install openssh-server

Now that this is configured we will download the relevant PuTTY files for windows from the link at the top of this post. When we are presented with the initial PuTTY screen we will simply input the hostname of our server. (You will have given your server a hostname when you first installed Ubuntu.) If you don't know your hostname or would like to connect via IPv4, try these commands in your terminal to identify the server:

eagle@server:~$ hostname
server
eagle@server:~$ ifconfig
          eth0 Link encap:Ethernet HWaddr 00:15:60:9e:2a:c7
          inet addr:192.168.1.200  Bcast:192.168.1.255  Mask:255.255.255.0
          UP BROADCAST MULTICAST MTU:1500 Metric:1
          RX packets:0 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
          TX packets:0 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
          collisions:0 txqueuelen:1000
          RX bytes:0 (0.0 B) TX bytes:0 (0.0 B)
          Interrupt:17

We can use either the hostname or the IP to connect to our server. We enter this into the Hostname or IP address field. Note that you can also prefix your username and the @ symbol to speed up the process. If you like you can highlight the Default Settings entry and click "Save" to overwrite the default blank menu with your username and server address. For me this is: eagle@192.168.1.200.

If your server is able to ping your other machine and vice versa then putty should connect without problems. After inputting your password you are greeted with the same old terminal interface that will behave just like the terminal on your actual server.

From here we will now configure the default package mirror for our server in the case that you have a preferred mirror.

I am with the Internode ISP and they have their own Ubuntu mirror and so before installing anything major I will tell Ubuntu to download files from this location instead of the public mirrors which would count toward my download quota. Ubuntu has a configuration file that tells it where to look for the package mirror. We find it in the following location and open it:

eagle@server:~$ cd /etc/apt
eagle@server:/etc/apt$ sudo nano sources.list

Don't forget to back up the file first! (See Part 2)

The following is a shortened version of what you will see in the file. I have omitted the comments to make this post more brief. I recommend, however, reading the comments to find out what's going on in this file. The file contents are below. Note that I've only highlighted the first few edits, you can see the pattern emerge:

#deb http://au.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ maverick main restricted
deb http://mirror.internode.on.net/pub/ubuntu/ubuntu/ maverick main restricted
#deb-src http://au.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ maverick main restricted
deb-src http://mirror.internode.on.net/pub/ubuntu/ubuntu/ maverick main restricted
#deb http://au.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ maverick-updates main restricted
deb http://mirror.internode.on.net/pub/ubuntu/ubuntu/ maverick-updates main restricted
#deb-src http://au.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ maverick-updates main restricted
deb-src http://mirror.internode.on.net/pub/ubuntu/ubuntu/ maverick-updates main restricted
#deb http://au.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ maverick universe
deb http://mirror.internode.on.net/pub/ubuntu/ubuntu/ maverick universe
#deb-src http://au.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ maverick universe
deb-src http://mirror.internode.on.net/pub/ubuntu/ubuntu/ maverick universe
#deb http://au.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ maverick-updates universe
deb http://mirror.internode.on.net/pub/ubuntu/ubuntu/ maverick-updates universe
#deb-src http://au.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ maverick-updates universe
deb-src http://mirror.internode.on.net/pub/ubuntu/ubuntu/ maverick-updates universe
#deb http://au.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ maverick multiverse
deb http://mirror.internode.on.net/pub/ubuntu/ubuntu/ maverick multiverse
#deb-src http://au.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ maverick multiverse
deb-src http://mirror.internode.on.net/pub/ubuntu/ubuntu/ maverick multiverse
#deb http://au.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ maverick-updates multiverse
deb http://mirror.internode.on.net/pub/ubuntu/ubuntu/ maverick-updates multiverse
#deb-src http://au.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ maverick-updates multiverse
deb-src http://mirror.internode.on.net/pub/ubuntu/ubuntu/ maverick-updates multiverse
You can see where in green I have "commented out" the default line and replaced it with my own. To find the correct URL for your own mirror you should visit the default URL and find a matching directory tree at your own mirror. To do this we highlight the line in putty and paste it into our browser. In my case it led me here. I then visited my ISP's mirror and made some educated guesses until I ended up in the spot with the same directory tree as the default URL had. I then appended the matching keywords and commented out the original, not removing it in case I wanted to revert the change later.

Note that I have left the security area of the file because my mirror does not mirror security patches and so this is left as is.
deb http://security.ubuntu.com/ubuntu maverick-security main restricted
deb-src http://security.ubuntu.com/ubuntu maverick-security main restricted
deb http://security.ubuntu.com/ubuntu maverick-security universe
deb-src http://security.ubuntu.com/ubuntu maverick-security universe
deb http://security.ubuntu.com/ubuntu maverick-security multiverse
deb-src http://security.ubuntu.com/ubuntu maverick-security multiverse
And so we save and close the file. Now we have replaced Ubuntu's default package mirror with our ISP's one. This is good because it lightens the load on Ubuntu's mirrors and means my packages and updates don't count toward my monthly downloads. Lastly we'll get Ubuntu to reconfigure itself to the new changes by running everyone's favourite update command:

eagle@server:~$ sudo apt-get update
...
Hit http://mirror.internode.on.net/pub/ubuntu/ubuntu/ maverick/restricted Translation-en_AU
...

This command ought now to spam you with entries from your desired mirror with no sign of the old Ubuntu mirror's URLs.

In conclusion, we have set up remote terminal access to our server machine via OpenSSH, an implementation of the SSH protocol. We have also customised the source of our server's package downloads. In Part 5 we will configure Ubuntu to take care of its own clock.

entry.title: Ubuntu File Server Part 3: Wireless Network
entry.content:
In Part 2 we looked at manually setting up our Ubuntu 10.10 Server x64 with basic wired networking configuration. To configure modern wireless networking with encryption and passwords another few packages are needed, wpasupplicant and wireless-tools. As always a decent guide was first found, and in this case fellow Blogger user Jeroen had just the guide I needed.

Jeroen makes the good point of updating Ubuntu's package list before installing anything to make sure we are getting the most up-to-date version of the software we desire. This process will use the wired network adapter that we configured previously.

eagle@server:~$ sudo apt-get update
eagle@server:~$ sudo apt-get install wireless-tools wpasupplicant

Now we have the necessary packages to configure the wireless network and tell our machine to connect to it.  Before we can go any further we must find out if Ubuntu can see our adapter and if so, what it has named our adapter. Unknown adapter driver installation is beyond the scope of this guide.

eagle@server:~$ lspci


Here we are looking for Network Controllers. Ethernet controllers are Ubuntu's way of describing wired adapters and it should show the brand of your network controller as well as its model. Ubuntu makes finding what we want in the big list of adapters easy, using the command line. Here I am using the grep command to return only lines that contain the String "Network"


eagle@server:~$ lspci | grep Network
05:09.0 Network controller: Atheros Communications Inc. AR5008 Wireless Network Adapter (rev 01)

Having found the adapter to be detected here, we go on to find out what it is listed as. Ubuntu uses the logical system of naming wireless adapters starting from wlan0 upward. We check this by using a command to show the current setup of the wireless controllers:

eagle@server:~$ iwconfig
lo no wireless extensions.

eth0 no wireless extensions.

wlan0 IEEE 802.11bgn ESSID:"Name"
          Mode:Managed Frequency:2.432 GHz Access Point: 00:04:ED:AC:28:6E
          Bit Rate=243 Mb/s Tx-Power=20 dBm
          Retry long limit:7 RTS thr:off Fragment thr:off
          Power Management:off
          Link Quality=42/70 Signal level=-68 dBm
          Rx invalid nwid:0 Rx invalid crypt:0 Rx invalid frag:0
          Tx excessive retries:0 Invalid misc:0 Missed beacon:0

Note that my wireless controller is already connected and your details may differ. The iwconfig command will only show the wireless configurations, so you can see it has ignored the loopback and ethernet adapters. Now we know what Ubuntu has called our wireless network adapter.

Next we will edit the Ubuntu network interface configuration file, which we already modified in Part 1 of this series. We navigate there and open it up:

eagle@server:~$ cd /etc/network
eagle@server:/etc/network$ sudo vim interfaces

In the file that we have opened, we can see the entries that we previously made and those in green we will add now:

# This file describes the network interfaces available on your system
# and how to activate them. For more information, see interfaces(5).

# The loopback network interface
auto lo
iface lo inet loopback

auto eth0
iface eth0 inet dhcp

auto wlan0
iface wlan0 inet dhcp
          wireless-ssid Name
          #this seems to tell the wpa supplicant to boot when connecting
          pre-up wpa_supplicant -B -Dwext -iwlan0 -c/etc/wpa_supplicant.conf
          #and this seem to tell it to die when disconnecting
          post-down killall -q wpa_supplicant

Above you can see a similar thing happens for the wireless adapter as for the wired adapter, except that we tell our machine to use the wpasupplicant program to supply the security settings for the network.

To this effect we need to configure the security setting that our machine will use to connect to the network of our choice. At the start of this part of the series we install the wpasupplicant package and this will supply the security settings to our adapter in order to connect to the wireless network.

Our wpasupplicant program is able to pull settings from a file that we create in the /etc/ directory and we will do this by browsing there and then creating a new file:

eagle@server:~$ cd /etc/
eagle@server:/etc$ sudo vim wpa_supplicant.conf

Inside this file we will write the following:
network={          ssid="same_as_we_entered_into_interfaces_config_file"          proto=RSN          key_mgmt=WPA-PSK          pairwise=CCMP TKIP          group=CCMP TKIP          psk="wireless_password"}
And now we can test our configuration to make sure that it works by using the command:

eagle@server:~$ cd /etc/init.d/networking restart

And now we have configured our server to connect to our local wireless network. In Part 4 we will look at how to configure package lists and remote control to our server.

entry.title: Ubuntu File Server Part 2: Wired Network
entry.content:
Continuing from Part 1 of this series have now installed Ubuntu 10.10 Server x64 using a monitor and keyboard but the machine isn't actually providing any services at all, and is not connected to any networks. In Part 1 I decided against the automatic configuration of my network in an attempt to learn how the process works.

In the following pages, it is important to remember to backup your current configurations before attempting to meddle on the command line. To this effect I will be playing with the network interfaces configuration file and hence, will back it up first.


eagle@server:~$ cd /etc/network
eagle@server:/etc/network$ ls
if-down.d  if-post-down.d  if-pre-up.d  if-up.d  interfaces
eagle@server:/etc/network$ sudo cp interfaces interfaces.bak
eagle@server:/etc/network$ ls
if-down.d  if-post-down.d  if-pre-up.d  if-up.d  interfaces  interfaces.bak


Also beware the sudo command. In these cases the files are in restricted parts of the file system such that an ordinary used (without sudo privelages) cannot mess up your finely tuned configuration files. Don't trust me, make sure you understand EVERY command you enter into your server.

Ubuntu will have detected most if not all network adapters present during installation. If yours is not you will have to use a network adapter that does work to install the correct drivers for the adapter that wasn't detected. This is, however, outside the scope of this post. In my case both the wired and wireless adapters were detected. We check using:


eagle@server:~$ ifconfig -a

          collisions:0 txqueuelen:0

          inet addr:192.168.1.200  Bcast:192.168.1.255  Mask:255.255.255.0

          collisions:0 txqueuelen:1000
          RX bytes:589915 (589.9 KB)  TX bytes:741627 (741.6 KB)


At the start of each section we can see the name of the adapter (eth0, lo and wlan0). These are the names Ubuntu has given our physical adapters as well as the loopback connection (lo).  We will configure the wired connection (eth0) for now.

First, a trip to the Google machine to find relevant guides. This article was found, but we must pay heed to the fact that it is for an older version of Ubuntu, so it may not work and may have different or primitive commands. We will now tell Ubuntu to use the wired connection and how to use it by browsing to the network interface configuration file and editing it.


eagle@server:~$ cd /etc/network
eagle@server:/etc/network$ sudo nano interfaces


Here we've used the built-in program nano to open the interfaces file, which will look something like this:

          # This file describes the network interfaces available on your system
          # and how to activate them. For more information, see interfaces(5).

          # The loopback network interface
          auto lo
          iface lo inet loopback

          auto eth0

          # and should get this address from a DHCP server

Our addition is seen in green, how it works was learnt from this page for an older Ubuntu Server release.

Now we plug in a network cable from the machine to the router and restart the networking service with the new settings.

eagle@server:~$ sudo /etc/init.d/networking restart

At this point we should be able to see output showing us the adapter procuring itself an IPv4 address from the router. We can confirm this with:

eagle@server:~$ ifconfig eth0

In Part 3 we will look at performing the same operation but instead using a wireless network adapter through a passworded local wireless network.

entry.title: Ubuntu File Server Part 1: Installation
entry.content:
The following posts will document my journey to replace a Windows 7 torrent and file serving machine with Ubuntu 10.10 Server x64.

I was inspired to try this after reading a post in the Ubuntu forums about an user's attempt at an Ubuntu based file server.

A great reference moving forward from here is the Ubuntu Server Guide. When linking there, always check you're looking at the right release of Ubuntu Server; I've found myself on articles for previous versions many times and wondered why I wasn't getting any joy. The Ubuntu server guide has large gaps, but is overall, a good place to begin any project.

I began by installing Ubuntu Desktop x64 hoping that I might be able to rely on the GUI if my CLI skills were not up to the task of configuring the machine. I soon found out that the desktop edition requires significant tweaking to work headless.

As it turns out, Teamviewer's Linux version runs under wine, working only as a window and not a service. I had intended to use Teamviewer to remote-desktop into the machine if CLI wasn't working out. Teamviewer can be added to the startup program list but then the machine would have to be configured to login to my account automatically. Most importantly, Ubuntu desktop edition is very unhappy (as of the time of this post) running without a monitor physically plugged in.

I am with the Internode ISP who host their own Ubuntu mirror, so a trip here yielded the relevant .iso file for download. The machine was booted into the Ubuntu installer. Nothing unusual here, just keyboard choice (USA) and user names.I decided to ignore the network setup and configure it manually to learn how things worked. I then decided to format the entire system drive and to configure LVM. Although I'm not sure of the benefits of the LVM choice, it sounded like the option that might give more flexibility. I didn't install any extra packages (SAMBA, OpenSSH) because I didn't want the installer holding my hand.

After this, the installation process just takes time to complete. The CD gets ejected and a reboot is done. You'll be booted into the terminal login screen.

At this point the machine has had Ubuntu 10.10 Server x64 installed onto it but was not providing any services nor was it connected to any networks.

The Ubuntu Server is really quick, mostly because no assumptions have been made about how you intend to use the server and what it is for. Because of this, we have to install and configure any functionality we desire, past the basic terminal interface and the bare essential programs to use the terminal interface. In Part 2 we will set up a basic wired network connection to get our server connected to the internet.
